issues.body:
No more code sharing!!! 🎉 🍰 🎆 👍 

NOTE: This is currently using a version directly off of `dotnet-core`, so we don't want to check it in until https://github.com/aspnet/Universe/pull/789 finishes.

For information about this change, see https://github.com/aspnet/Announcements/issues/283

The overwrite should be optional. Different implementations will have different features, bugs, perf, etc..
Sure maybe a flag to overwrite then.
:shipit:
7.5.1 - Send a close frame with invalid UTF8 payload - Clean close with protocol error or invalid utf8 code or dropped TCP.

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-5.6

```
   Text

      The "Payload data" is text data encoded as UTF-8.  Note that a
      particular text frame might include a partial UTF-8 sequence;
      however, the whole message MUST contain valid UTF-8.  Invalid
      UTF-8 in reassembled messages is handled as described in
      Section 8.1.
```

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-8.1 - Handling Errors in UTF-8-Encoded Data
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-10.7 - Handling of Invalid Data
Updated. The utf-8 validation has been completed and now 100% of the autobahn tests pass.
Now passing with 100%.
@victorhurdugaci @muratg
Assuming the tests work now on Win7, :shipit:
:shipit:
CLA approved. @Tratcher to merge.
@muratg can you find someone to work on this?
ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read the data in Netmon. It just makes the masking step a no-op so it should work with any server.
@Tratcher I moved the ZeroMask discussion to https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/issues/27 so we could treat it separately.

ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read your data in Netmon. 0 is a legal mask per spec, just not recommended (see http://xkcd.com/221/). It makes the masking step a no-op, but servers shouldn't even notice.
I think once you invoke an XKCD comic it becomes truth.

Is this still relevant @Tratcher @muratg @Eilon ? If so, we should move it to beta6
Yes, moved to beta6.

The synchronization you see in CommonWebSocket is used to prevent Ping/Pongs from colliding with user Sends. See:
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L377
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L164
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L124
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L489

This also happens to protect a user from calling Send multiple times by mistake, but that does not mean concurrent sends are actually supported.  You can see by the way the locks work that the user gets no benefit from calling Send multiple times at the moment. If it becomes a problem then we can add additional checks to notify users when they call send multiple times by mistake.
We can consider using a Task queue.
We already use SemaphoreSlim.WaitAsync, so it's async blocking.

IMO it's very important in xplat/pluggable libraries like WebSockets implementation to maintain exactly the same semantics (including error handling) among different implementations/platform. One could depend on implementation specifics for example task queuing on async semaphore instead of providing upper level buffering/queuing and for example application will work correctly when .NET Core self-hosted but will fail under Helios throwing InvalidOperationException.

Interestingly the MSDN docs do not specify a required semantic: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.websockets.websocket.sendasync(v=vs.110).aspx

I understand the portability concern. Since the overlapped sends are not fully supported we should actively discourage developers at runtime from doing it (e.g. throw).

That said, if we decided to support overlapped sends in a specific implementation, we may do that even if other implementations didn't. Consistency is good, but sometimes we diverge on purpose to add value. Otherwise we'd never need more than one implementation.  We just need to be clear about the differences and why you'd use one over the other.

Yeah exactly. Unclear semantics on such core APIs are one of the root causes of inefficient networking implementations or portability issues. That's exactly why I started from browsing source code of different implementations due to lack of official documentation on this problem.

In case you decide to add support for Overlapped Sends/Receives please consider adding: `bool SupportsOverlapped { get; }` or something like that with clear semantics. In such situation libraries utilizing WebSocket can check for this flag and make use of optimization you are implementing ;).

For example I am implementing an xplat RPC library over web sockets and want it to be as efficient as possible (especially in terms of latency) but also interopable (working among different kinds of hosts).

FYI, `RNGCryptoServiceProvider` is not yet available on CoreCLR, so we'll have to continue using `System.Random` there. Mono does have a `RNGCryptoServiceProvider` implementation that uses `/dev/random` or `/dev/urandom` on *nix. We'd need to sync up with CoreCLR on the plan for implementing this there.

Whether SendAsync and ReceiveAsync can be used simultaneously needs to be clarified as well.

Some 'typical' websocket use-cases which benefit from concurrent operation support:
- sending the same data to a number of client WebSockets (you don't want to await the Send for each client)
- sending event notifications from multiple independent sources to a client WebSocket
- accepting commands on a WebSocket and providing the reply after async execution (multiple replies can occur simultaneously)

The .NET Core team is working on a cross platform websocket client post RTM.

https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/tree/master/src/System.Net.WebSockets.Client/src/System/Net/WebSockets

The ping/pongs serve two purposes:
1. They encourage the connection to stay open with occasional traffic (with emphasis on the occasional; 1 second is very high, 30 seconds is more common).
2. Detecting if the connection has been broken. Any outgoing write on a broken connection will trigger a reset from the remote party, causing the pending read on that connection to fail.

So the answer to your real question is that you detect the client disconnect by always keeping a pending read on the WebSocket. Note that the current implementation requires this to process incoming pings anyways.

thanks for the quick follow-up. the use-case i am most concerned with is a half-open state, say, by losing a wireless connection or having an ethernet cable unplugged.

enforcing a read-timeout on the underlying TCP stream is one way to check for an unplugged cable.

it's not clear how sending a ping, by itself, is enough to verify the client is still connected (if the client is unreachable), unless you are willing to wait for the TCP protocol itself to timeout (which may be a long time).

I tried to set up a standalone C# repro but the C# WebSocket libraries do not give access to sending ping frames, which is required to reproduce this issue, so I've done what I can to make the Autobahn Test Suite case easy to reproduce.

**Setup:**
1. Install CPython 2.7 - https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-2712/
1. Install Microsoft Visual C++ Compiler for Python 2.7 - http://aka.ms/vcpython27
2. Run `python -m ensurepip`
3. Run `pip install autobahntestsuite`
4. Run `wstest --help` to verify the test suite is installed

**Repro:**
1. Clone this repo, check out `anurse/100-repro`
2. Open WebSockets.sln in VS, and launch AutobahnTestApp in the IIS Express launch profile
3. Upon launching, the browser should pop and display the WebSocket URL for the server
4. Open PowerShell, cd to the `test\AutobahnTestApp` directory in this repo
5. Run `.\scripts\RunAutobahnTests.ps1 -ServerUrl [WEB SOCKET URL HERE] -Cases "5.7" -Iterations 20`

**Expected Behavior:** All iterations pass.

**Actual Behavior:** Some iterations will fail.

The test case is simply sending three frames:
- Opcode 1 (Text Frame) EndOfMessage=false "fragment1"
- Opcode 9 (Ping Frame) EndOfMessage=true "ping payload"
- Opcode 0 (Continuation Frame) EndOfMessage=true "fragment2"

The tests fail intermittently and without pattern. However, they do reliably fail within about 5-10 iterations. Something on the IIS end is dropping the connection because if you repeat the same tests directly against Kestrel it passes reliably (so far I've tried 100 iterations in sequence).

The issue **does reproduce in both IIS and IIS Express**
